data.title: Tilemap not showing tiles when tileset are added by code
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 7 64bit
release version 2.0.2 or 2.1 alpha custom build

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
var ts = TileSet.new()
tilemap.set_tileset(ts)
only show tiles in Tilemap when he has a dummy tileset added by hand

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. create a scene (*.TSCN or *.SCN)
2. add a tilemap node
3. create tileset by gdscript and add it with set_tileset() to tilemap node

```
func _ready():
    var ts = TileSet.new()
    for i in range(10):
        ts.create_tile(i)
        ts.tile_set_texture(i,newTexture(imageSize))
        ts.tile_set_name(i,str(i))
    get_node("TileMap").set_tileset(ts)
    for i in range(10):
        for j in range(10):
            get_node("TileMap").set_cell(5+i,5+j,j,false,false,false)
    get_node("TileMap").set_cell_size(imageSize)
```
1. play scene
2. nothing is displayed
3. stop scene
4. click on tilemap node
5. chose Tile Set --> New TileSet
6. play scene
7. everything works
   ![bug_with_set_tileset](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10463138/15839880/6ca4c2f4-2c46-11e6-8b32-5831ee958fec.gif)

data.title: Fix error tab index out of size print, issue 4997

closes #4997

data.title: Add missing license information for bundled libraries
AnimatedSprite3D doesn't recognize its frames
data.body:
**OS, GPU, Version** 
Linux 4.5.2 x86_64 01:00.0 
VGA compatible controller: NVIDIA Corporation GK106 [GeForce GTX 645 OEM](rev a1)
"Nouveau" driver
Godot 955ed0a95f61e14e6c941540b11905a16fb40d00

**Issue description** 
The AnimatedSprite3D doesn't recognize its frames.
No frame is displayed in editor and when running it in editor.
Git bisect hints that it might also be the case for AnimatedSprite(2D) but I haven't tested it yet.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Start the editor
Create a new AnimatedSprite3D
Load frames into the AnimatedSprite3D
-> Nothing is displayed in editor, current frame can't be changed.

**Git bisect**

bed3efb17ede58a2bfc177b47cb3a49091aea30a is the first bad commit
commit bed3efb17ede58a2bfc177b47cb3a49091aea30a
Author: Juan Linietsky reduzio@gmail.com
Date:   Sat May 14 23:48:23 2016 -0300

```
New reworked AnimatedSprite!

-New SpriteFrames editor, with support for drag&drop, multiple animation
sets, animation speed and loop.
-New AnimatedSprite, with support for all the new features!
AnimatedSprite3D has not been updated yet.
-Added support for drag&drop to other editors, such as resourcepreload,
sample library,  etc.
```

:040000 040000 66f4fb20db05558f21096625d351686d6abc8a51 77c244cadb797700560b1cfc0bb7c335c462a295 M  scene

data.title: Keep the default environment variables as set by SCons
data.body:
Fixes a regression introduced by  #4179 by which cross-building on Windows would fail because of the SystemRoot env var not being present.
That makes the toolchains to fail to find certain system DLLs.
I noticed this while trying to build for Android with GCC 4.9 on Windows. g++ crashed and that was the reason.

data.title: want to use resources wav avi bmp
data.body:
my game uses external resources that may contain wav, avi, bmp files.

so I wish godot can use resources *.wav *.avi *.bmp on running.

data.title: Change CodeText Size on the fly.
data.body:
Changing the script size on the fly would be cool for creating tutorials. People are complaining they cannot follow the code very well because it is to small.
Could be a cool addition to change the font size with for example ctrl+mousewheel. That way you can quickly adjust the code font size without the need to restart the editor.

data.title: Somewhat fixed Directory::get_space_left() return values.
data.body:
Implemented it on windows using `GetDiskFreeSpaceEx()`.
Works on linux/osx(if STAT_VFS is enabled) and windows. On other platforms currently returns 0.

Partly fixes #4617 , only Android implementation remaining. I'm not sure what proper behavior for `DirAccessPack` is.

data.title: Preserve signal connections when replacing target node
data.body: Fixes #1461

data.title: Improved Blender/Collada -colonly import creating collision shapes fo
data.body:
r empties

It would be nice to create StaticBodies / ColisionShapes for Empties imported from blender.
Blender has plenty of Empty types and some of them can be mapped to Godot collision shapes.

My proposal is to map:
CUBE -> BoxShape
IMAGE -> PlaneShape
SINGLE_ARROW -> RayShape
SPHERE -> SphereShape
anything else -> SphereShape

![blender](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/19764492/15807641/72445320-2b63-11e6-9439-83fceb7eafe2.png)

![godot](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/19764492/15807643/79cae8b6-2b63-11e6-9d45-6965342ded9c.png)

data.title: Bitmask import plugin
data.body: Although the method to produce one from a transluscent texture existed, there didn't appear to be an in-editor option to create the binary mask files used for TextureButtons, so I've added a simple one.

data.title: Added missing icons for some nodes, changed instance icon
Fix implicit GDScript Reference inheritance
data.body: Currently, applying a GDScript without `extends` to a non-Reference type (e.g. a Node) will not yield an error but result in a somewhat ambiguous state. Lack of explicit `extends` should result in an implicit `extends Reference`. This change fixes the behavior accordingly.

data.title: MOUSE_MODE_CAPTURED does not hide the cursor
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10 64bit - Godot 2.1 alpha custom build.

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
When using `Input.set_mouse_mode(Input.MOUSE_MODE_CAPTURED)` the cursor is not hidden.

MOUSE_MODE_CAPTURED should hide the mouse, or alternatively a new mouse mode MOUSE_MODE_CAPTURED_HIDDEN could be used for both capturing and hiding the mouse.

I believe the problem might have started with this commit b5e0729 (but I can't test if that's true)

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
The demo "Window Management" has a button to capture the mouse.

data.title: GDScript performance improvement via Just-in-time (JIT) compilation
data.body:
What about adopting just-in-time (JIT) compilation for GDscripts?

JIT compilation has no disadvantages over interpreted code (aside from slower startup, in some cases) and many advantages, mainly in terms of performance.

For JIT compilation, there are at least two popular ways to implement it in a cross-platform way without writing any code from scratch:
- [LLVM Intermediate Representation](http://llvm.org/docs/LangRef.html)
- [DynASM](http://luajit.org/dynasm.html), used in LuaJIT

There is also the option of using PyPy, the JVM or the CLR, but those are quite heavier, using [GNU Lightning](https://www.gnu.org/software/lightning/) or [libjit](https://www.gnu.org/software/libjit/) (not sure if the license is compatible with Godot's) and of course, writing a code generator from scratch (which could take years).

So, the choice is pretty much between **LLVM IR** and **DynASM**. Both have very good performance, but DynASM is written in Lua and LLVM has a fairly large footprint (~20MB), but also offers other features.

Of course, compiling GDScript directly to C++ could also be a valid alternative - the only game engine which does it that I know of (if I understood it correctly) is [Enigma](http://enigma-dev.org/), which compiles its own scripting language (EDL) to C++.

What do you think about this?

data.title: Added Dictionary.values()
data.body:
There was no easy way to get an Array of Dictionary values. The best being something like:

```
var values = []
for key in dict:
    values.push_back(dict[key])
```

now that is equal to:
`var values = dict.values()`

Also synced classref and documented `Dictionary.values()`.
